section.title: Forward Rates
section.p: In addition to spot rates, we can also describe how we expect interest rates to vary in the near future using forward rates. Forward rates are interest rates that are locked in today (at time 0), but are only in effect for a period of time at some point in the future (i.e., at some point forward in time). The typical notation is \iota_0(t-k,t), which stands for the effective periodic interest measured now but is in effect between times t-k and t.

li.p: The time t (or t-time) forward rate (note that this refers to the ending time).

section.p: You may also see \iota_0(t-k,t) described as "the t\! -\! k deferred t-year interest rate." There may be other equivalent terms you encounter, as well as alternate notation. As usual, refer to context to understand what the author intends.
